sections.heading: Highlights
sections.text:
1. Nano-MgO was successfully prepared by homogeneous precipitation method. 2. Nano-MgO exhibited high catalytic activity for quinoline removal in
ozonation process.
3. Nine intermediates were identified and the degradation pathway was proposed. 4. Nano-MgO can facilitate ozone decomposition and act via a hydroxyl radical
mechanism.
5. Catalytic ozonation pretreatment improved the biodegradability of biologically
pretreated coal gasification wastewater.

sections.heading: Abstract
sections.text:
Nano-MgO was prepared by homogeneous precipitation method and applied for
the degradation of quinoline. The characterization of the catalyst was determined by X-ray diffraction (XRD), Fourier Transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET), Transmission Electron Microscope (TEM) and Energy Dispersive Spectrometer (EDS). The results showed that the presence of nano-MgO significantly improved the degradation and mineralization of quinoline. Nine intermediates were identified by liquid chromatograph-tandem mass spectrometer (LC-MS/MS), gas chromatograph and mass spectrometry (GC-MS) and ion chromatograph (IC) analysis. And a possible degradation pathway of quinoline in catalytic ozonation was proposed. The change of dissolved ozone concentration and the effect of tert butyl alcohol (TBA) and phosphate indicated that the prepared catalyst could enhance ozone decomposition into hydroxyl radicals, which was considered to be mainly responsible for the pollutants removal. In addition, catalytic ozonation pretreatment was applied for the treatment of biologically pretreated coal gasification wastewater. The results demonstrated that catalytic ozonation pre-treatment improved the biodegradability of wastewater containing quinoline in terms of BOD5/COD (B/C), toxicity and resazurin dehydrogenase activity (DHA), indicating the potential of catalytic ozonation integrated with biosystem for this type of wastewater. This study would assist in obtaining a better understanding of the application of catalytic ozonation pre-treatment in biologically pretreated coal gasification wastewater.
Keywords: Quinoline; Nano-MgO; Catalytic ozonation; Biologically pretreated coal gasification wastewater

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Quinoline, a representative of nitrogen-heterocyclic compounds, is a part of
structural component of many antiseptics, antibiotics and other pharmaceuticals [1]. It is often used as raw materials and solvents in the manufacture of paints, dyes, herbicides and other fine chemicals. In addition, it occurs widely in coal tar, mineral oil, petroleum and industry wastewater including coking wastewater, coal gasification wastewater and pharmaceutical wastewater, etc [1,2]. With a nitrogen-atom incorporated in the ring system, quinoline has higher water resolvability than its homocyclic analogues and is easy to accumulate in water environments. Specially, quinoline and its derivatives accounted for 27.4% of organic pollutants in coal gasification wastewater [2]. Improper discharge of the particular pollutants such as quinoline contributes to their occurrence in secondary effluent of coal gasification wastewater due in part to their relatively high solubility and low biodegradation [3]. Quinoline inhibits microorganisms growth by influencing its biodegradation and once released into the environment, it exhibits significant threats to the plants, animals and human beings because of their toxicity, carcinogenicity and mutagenicity [4-7]. And it has been considered as a priority organic pollutant by the US Environmental Protection Agency [2]. Therefore, it is great significance to develop efficient treatment techniques for limiting the presence of quinoline in wastewater.
In recent years, advanced oxidation methods (AOPs) have been widely used for
the removal of quinoline, including wet oxidation [8], O3/UV [9], electrochemical oxidation [2], UV photolysis [10]. As an alternative, heterogeneous catalytic
ozonation was found to be very effective for eliminating toxic pollutants in wastewater [11]. In this process, a catalyst was employed to accelerate ozone decomposition to generate hydroxyl radicals. These non-selective radicals are capable of oxidizing toxic pollutants to convert them into readily biodegradable compounds.
The most widely used catalysts in heterogeneous catalytic ozonation are metal
oxides, metals (Cu, Ru, Pt, Co) on supports (SiO2, Al2O3, TiO2, CeO2 and activated carbon), zeolites modified with metals and activated carbon [12]. Many metal oxides such as MnO2 [13-16], MgO [17], ZnO [18], TiO2 [19,20], CeO2 [21], aluminum oxides [22] and iron oxides [23] have been applied as catalysts. Among these catalysts, MgO has showed good catalytic performance for the degradation of several types of water and wastewater pollutants due to its high efficient activity, structural stability, environment friendliness and low toxicity [24-28]. MgO exhibited significant catalytic activity for several pollutants including 4-chlorophenol and dyes [29,30]. Also, MgO loaded on GAC can activate O3 to form more hydroxyl radicals, which is favorable for catalytic ozonation [31,32]. However, the above-mentioned MgO was prepared by conventional thermal decomposition, which sometimes affected its catalytic activity [33]. The homogeneous precipitation method is a promising procedure of synthesizing MgO due to its easy operation, available raw materials, moderate cost and high efficiency [34]. Therefore, the catalytic efficacy of MgO can be improved by using this method. Nevertheless, the complete mineralization requires lots of excessive expenses in single chemical oxidation and sometimes highly toxic intermediates might be produced inevitably [35]. Hence, the study on the
biodegradability and toxicity assessment of intermediates has attracted much attention [36-38]. To our best knowledge, no study could be found on heterogeneous catalytic ozonation with nano-MgO as a catalyst for the removal of quinoline both in aqueous solution and biologically pretreated coal gasification wastewater.
In this work, nano-MgO was synthesized successfully and their properties were
characterized. The study focused on four aspects: (1) evaluation of catalytic performance of quinoline; (2) determination of intermediates and its possible pathways in catalytic ozonation of quinoline; (3) elucidation of the catalytic mechanism; (4) study on the application of nano-MgO in biologically pretreated coal gasification wastewater. The aim of this study was to provide a promising catalyst and develop a new understanding of catalytic ozonation of wastewater containing quinoline.

sections.heading: 2. Materials and methods
sections.text:
2.1. Materials and reagents
Quinoline, TBA, magnesium chloride (MgCl2â€¢6H2O), polyving akohol (PVA),
sodium hydroxide (NaOH), disodium hydrogen phosphate (Na2HPO4) and sodium thiosulfate (Na2S2O3) were purchased from Tianjin Kermel Chemical Reagents Company (Tianjin, China). Intermediates were obtained from Aladdin Industrial Corporation (Shanghai, China). All solutions were prepared with deionized water.
The real biologically pretreated coal gasification wastewater was obtained from
the effluent of secondary settling tank in the full-scale wastewater treatment facility and its water quality parameters were as follows: 150-180 mg/L of COD, 0.05-0.08 of
B/C, 60-70 mg/L of total organic carbon (TOC), 50-60 mg/L of total nitrogen (TN), 20-30 mg/L of NH3-N and pH value of 7.5-8.5. 2.2. Preparation and characterization of MgO catalyst
The MgO was prepared by homogeneous precipitation. First, 20 g MgCl2â€¢6H2O
was dissolved in 1 L deionized water. Then, 0.2 g PVA was added into the solution and magnetically stirred at 200 rpm for 1 h. 30 ml of NaOH (6 M) was slowly dripped into the prepared solution and the solution was aged for 24 h at room temperature. Subsequently, the precipitates were centrifuged at 4000 rpm for 10 min and washed with deionized water and ethanol for three times to removal the surface impurities. The washed precipitates were dried at 120 â„ƒ for 12 h. Finally, the power was calcined at 500 â„ƒ for 2 h under air atmosphere.
The crystal phase of MgO catalyst was detected by a XRD analyzer (Rigaku,
Japan) in the 2Î¸ in the range of 10-80Âº. The specific surface area and the pore size were determined by BET instrument (ASAP 2000, USA). The infrared spectra of MgO catalyst was taken on a FTIR spectrum apparatus (PerkinElmer Spectrum 100, USA). TEM was specified by JEM 1400 and EDS was determined using Phenom Prox. The pH at the point of zero charge (pHzc) was measured with a titration method. Particle size distribution was measured by Nano-s (Malvern, England). 2.3. Catalytic ozonation experiments
The experiments were carried out in a cylindrical water-jacketed reactor (internal
diameter of 9 cm and working height of 25 cm) with a total working volume of 1 L, which operated in a semi-batch mode. The reactor consisted of an O3 supply system
and an exhaust treatment system. Ozone was generated in dry air by an ozone generator (ANSEROS, COM-AD-01) and was introduced continuously into the solution at the bottom of the reactor through a porous glass diffuser with a desired gas flow rate of 40 L/h in the experiment process. When the gas flow rate was constant, the gas ozone concentration was controlled by power knob. The exhaust gas was further treated with a 20% KI solution to absorb the effluent O3. The reacted solution was perfectly mixed by a magnetic stirrer agitated at 400 rpm. All experiments were carried out at room temperature.
For catalytic ozonation experiments, to simulate the real wastewater, 20 mg/L of
quinoline and 0.2 g catalyst were added into the reactor. Then applied concentration of ozone in the gas was controlled at 2 mg/L. During the run, aliquots was taken from the reactor at predefined time points and quenched in samples by adding a concentrated solution of sodium thiosulfate or purged with high-purity N2 for 5 min to remove residual ozone. Then, the suspension of each sample was filtered with the 0.22 um filters and the filtrate was analyzed for the targeted parameters. After each run, the catalysts were centrifuged and washed with deionized water and dried at 100 â„ƒ for reuse. In addition, a control test of oxygen purging with the catalyst under the same conditions was conducted to discard the effect of adsorption of MgO during the experiments. Experiments were performed in triplicate and average values were presented. 2.4. Biodegradability index, toxicity assessment and resazurin dehydrogenase activity
The activated sludge used in the bioassays for biodegradability and toxicity was
taken from the A/O tank in the full-scale wastewater treatment plant [39].
Biochemical oxygen demand (BOD5) to chemical oxygen demand (COD) was
adopted as biodegradability index. BOD5 and COD were analyzed according to standard methods for examination of water and wastewater [40].
Toxicity assessment referred to the previous study [38]. Briefly, the test was
carried out in a glass reactor with 1 L of endogenous activated sludge at a constant temperature 20 . Dissolved oxygen concentration was determined by dissolved oxygen meter. This test compared the oxygen uptake of the target sample with that of the reference sample. 30 mL of sample was added into the glass reactor to obtain the OUR-sample and 30 ml of distilled water with 0.5 g of sodium acetate g-1 VSS was injected to gain the OUR-reference. The inhibition percentages were calculated by the Eq. (1):
(%) 100 (1 ) OUR sample

Resazurin dehydrogenase activity (DHA) was described by the previous method
[41]. Resazurin, as an electron receptor that can substitute for the electron transport of the respiratory chain, was applied to measure the dehydrogenase activity of microorganisms to characterize the biodegradability, due to its easy operation and strong electrophilic ability. Several centrifugal tubes (20 mL) were needed for the experiments. First, endogenous activated sludge (2.5 mL) and the sample (2.5 mL) were added to the tube and reacted for thirty minutes. Then resazurin (0.5 mL) was put into the tube. Thirty minutes later, Na2CO3 (5 mL) was added to terminate the reaction [42]. Then, the tube was centrifuged at a rate of 3000 rpm for 5 minutes and
the absorbance of supernatant was analyzed at 610 nm. The DHA can be calculated by the Eq. (2):

absorbance; Îµ is molar absorption coefficient; V is the total volume; t is the reaction time of resazurin. 2.5. Analytical method
The concentration of quinoline was analyzed using a liquid chromatograph
(HPLC, LC-1200, Agilent, USA) with an Agilent C18 (150mmÃ—4.6mm). The mobile phase was 60% methanol and 40% water and the wavelength of quinoline was 313nm. The ozone concentration in the gas was monitored by ozone gas detection instrument and dissolved ozone concentration was determined via the indigo method [43]. TOC was monitored via a TOC analyzer (TOC-VCPH, Shimadzu, Japan). pH value was determined with a pH meter (pHS-3C, Leici, China) and pH value automatic control was used for the test of pH effect. The identification of intermediates was performed by an Agilent 1290 LC equipped with an Agilent 6460 Triple Quadrupole mass spectrometer system in selected ion monitoring mode (SIM). The mobile phase was a mixture of A (95% water, 5% methanol, 0.1% formic acid and 5 mmol/L ammonium acetate) and B (5% water, 95% methanol, 0.1% formic acid and 5 mmol/L ammonium acetate) and it was followed gradient elution mode: (1) 100% A was maintained for the first 1 minute; (2) from 1 to 10 min, A decreased to 50%, while B increased from 0% to 50%; (3) from 10 to 11.5min, A reduced to 10%,while B increased to 90%; (4)
from 11.5 to 11.6min, the mobile phase was changed to the initial state until the whole 15min run. The flow rate was 0.3 L/min and the injection volume was 5 ÂµL. The mass data were acquired under positive ion mode except for quinolinic acid. Intermediates were confirmed using characteristic MS ions and matching LC retention time. The gas temperature and source voltage were 300 and 3.5 KV, respectively.
For GC-MS, the 20 mL aqueous solution from the reactor was extracted either at
natural pH or at 3 with twice ca. 10 mL dichloromethane. 1.0 mL of organic phase was analyzed after rotary evaporation and nitrogen-blow procedure. The intermediates were identified using GC-MS.
The identification of formic acid, acetic acid and oxalic acid was conducted by
ion chromatography according to the previous study [44].
3. Results and discussion 3.1. Catalyst characterization
The MgO catalyst was characterized using XRD, FTIR, BET, TEM and EDS to
study the catalyst properties. (see Supplementary Material Fig.S1-S2 and Test S1).
XRD pattern of Fig.S1a showed periclase MgO crystalline powers, indicating
purifies of the prepared catalysts. According to Fig.S1b of FTIR, the peak at 1456 cm-1 represented the stretching vibration Mg-O [45]. The MgO catalyst presented a specific surface area of 56.1 m2/g with a total pore volume of 0.152 cm3/g and a main pore size ranged from 10 to 50 nm from the results of BET analysis in Fig.S1c -S1d.
As were shown in Fig.S2a of TEM, the catalysts showed an irregular and
aggregated shape with the average size of < 50nm. In addition, it was found that
carbon (3.1%), magnesium (55.8%) and oxygen (41.1%) were the main elements in the prepared catalyst from EDS of Fig.S2b. 3.2. Catalytic efficacy
Fig.1 showed the degradation and mineralization of quinoline in adsorption,
ozonation and catalytic ozonation. Results presented in Fig.1a indicated that quinoline adsorption on MgO was around 1% after 15 min, thus the small adsorption can be neglected, suggesting that the degradation of quinoline was mainly due to the oxidation in the solution. Quinoline degradation was only 53.8% after 15 min in single ozonation. Compared with adsorption and single ozonation, the introduction of catalyst MgO led to 90.7% quinoline degradation under the same conditions. Corresponding to the TOC variation, based on the results obtained in Fig.1b, only 2% TOC was removed by the adsorption. The reduction of TOC was 32.5% in sole ozonation process, while with the presence of MgO, an improvement in the TOC reduction was achieved. The experimental results indicated that catalyst MgO has a synergistic effect for the degradation of quinoline. 3.3. Catalytic mechanisms and pathways 3.3.1. The change of ozone concentration in solution
Based on the results from adsorption experiments, it was observed that quinoline
absorbed on MgO can be ignored. It indicated that there was no distinct reaction between quinoline and the catalyst, thus the interaction between ozone and the catalyst was supposed to be an efficient way for the degradation of quinoline. In order to study the relationship between ozone and the catalyst, the change of dissolved
ozone concentration with continuous gas ozone was investigated. As shown in Fig.2, ozone concentration in solution increased rapidly and then reached equilibrium in both process in the first 3 min. With the presence of the catalyst, the equilibrium ozone concentration (0.38 mg/L) was much lower than that in single ozonation (0.78 mg/L), indicating the addition of the catalyst significantly enhanced ozone decomposition and thus reduced equilibrium ozone concentration in the solution. The result was similar to the previous studies when using other types of ozone catalysts [46,47], suggesting the catalyst played an important role in the catalytic degradation of quinoline. 3.3.2. Effect of pH
The solution pH played a critical role in catalytic ozonation, since it can
influence surface properties of catalyst, dissociation constants (pKa) and the generation of active radicals [48,49].

The pH at the point of zero charge (pHzc) of catalyst was measured to be 7.2 in
the experiments. As seen in Fig.3, it was observed that the catalytic ozonation substantially enhanced quinoline degradation from 82.5% to 94.8% at pH 4.5-7.2. Whereas, at 7.2 < pH < 11.3, the quinoline removal decreased to 79.8% at pH 11.3. The surface hydroxyl groups were the active sites for the production of hydroxyl radicals [11]. The surface of catalyst became protonated or deprotonated when solution pH was below or above its pHzc (Eq. (3) and Eq. (4)). At pHzc 7.2, its
surface hydroxyl groups would be mostly zero charged, and the quinoline degradation reached the maximum, suggesting that zero charged surface of MgO was more active than the protonated or deprotonated form in favoring the formation of â€¢OH. This was consistent with the results of Ren et al. [50] that zero-charged surface hydroxyl groups were mainly responsible for the degradation of di-n-butyl phthalate compared with its protonated or deprotonated form. Furthermore, it was mentioning that at pH 4.5, quinoline (pKa=4.9) was cationic and the electrostatic repulsion between cationic quinoline and positively charged catalyst may lead to the reduction in quinoline degradation. At pH 8.3 or 11.3, as were shown by Eq. (4), more MO- generated with the increasing of OH-. It was known that OH- could initiate aqueous ozone decomposition to produce hydroxyl radicals, while quinoline degradation decreased under the pH value of 8.3 or 11.3 compared with that of pHzc, indicating the dominating role of the surface property of mental oxide in influencing the catalytic activity, rather than OH- ions. 3.3.3. Effect of hydroxyl radical scavengers
In order to understand the role of â€¢OH in single and catalytic ozonation process,
TBA was selected as a probe, because it was a well-known radical scavenger that has reaction rate constants of 6.0Ã—108 M-1S-1 and 3.0Ã—10-3 M-1S-1 with â€¢OH and ozone, respectively. Meanwhile, TBA can hardly be absorbed on metal oxides due to its physicochemical characteristics [51].
As revealed in Fig.4, the presence of TBA inhibited quinoline degradation in
both ozone alone and catalytic ozonation. At 15 min oxidation time, quinoline
degradation reached 90.7% in catalytic ozonation and 53.8% in ozonation alone. However, with the addition of TBA, quinoline degradation decreased by 64.2% and 27.7% in O3 / MgO and single ozonation. Compared with ozonation alone, a 36.5 % increment in inhibition was observed in catalytic process in the presence of TBA, indicating catalytic ozonation of quinoline followed the hydroxyl radical reaction mechanisms. 3.3.4. Effect of phosphate
Phosphate, as a common ligand, can lead to a substitution of the acid Lewis sites
[52]. In order to further understand the relationship between ozone and the catalyst, phosphate was employed in ozonation and catalytic ozonation process.
The effect of phosphate (1g/L, pH=6.8, adjusted by disodium hydrogen
phosphate) on quinoline degradation was shown in Fig.5. As indicated in Fig.5, the introduction of phosphate has little effect on quinoline degradation in single ozonation. However, catalytic activity of MgO was significantly suppressed when phosphate was introduced into the system. The presence of phosphate occupied the Lewis acid sites and thus the interaction between ozone and catalyst was inhibited. The experimental results further proved that the reaction between ozone and catalyst played an important role in catalytic ozonation of quinoline. 3.3.5. Mechanisms and pathways of quinoline degradation
Generally, catalytic ozonation with MgO mainly involves two mechanisms:
direct reaction with ozone and indirect reaction with the radicals produced from the interaction between ozone and catalyst. Each reaction can take place both in the
catalyst surface and the solution [17,24,30]. These proposed mechanisms can be simplified as:
In the solution phase:

MgO-s means the acid Lewis sites of the catalyst. To ascertain the mechanisms dominating the interaction of ozone with the
catalyst for quinoline removal in the catalytic ozonation process in this study, the dissolved ozone concentration with and without catalyst as well as the effect of pH, TBA and phosphate were analyzed. From the results of the effect of TBA, it can be concluded that indirect reaction with â€¢OH was the main mechanism involved in degradation of quinoline in the catalytic ozonation process through the reaction given in Eq. (6). The analysis of effect of pH indicated that the surface hydroxyl groups played an important role in the catalytic ozonation of quinoline. The finding of change of dissolved ozone and the effect of phosphate further proved that the catalyst could enhance ozone into hydroxyl radicals, as shown in Eq. (9)-Eq. (10). Another possible
mechanism of Eq. (8) could be slightly involved due to the little adsorption of quinoline (around 1%) on the catalyst, as were shown in Fig.1. Other reactions such as Eq. (7) and Eq. (11) may also participate in the catalytic ozonation process, which were required to be further proved. Detailed proposed mechanisms in this study were revealed in Fig.6.
The intermediates of the catalytic ozonation of quinoline determined by
LC-MS/MS, GC-MS and IC were shown in Table 1. The mass spectrum of P1 to P6 was provided in the supplementary material.
Fig.7 proposes the possible pathways of quinoline degradation in the catalytic
ozonation process. As seen in Fig.7, quinoline was first initiated by hydroxylation at C(2) and C(8) position of the aromatic ring, leading to the formation of 2-hydroxyquinoline (P1) and 8-hydroxyquinoline (P2). The hydroxylation can occur via the electrophilic attack of molecular ozone or the hydroxyl radical attack. After that, a broken on 3-4 double bond of quinoline resulted in the production of formamide, n-phenyl- (P6) and o-amino benzaldehyde (P3) by an unstable ozonide or â€¢OH. P3 was further oxidized into salicylic acid (P4). Following the same mechanism, P2 proceeded to generate quinolinic acid (P5) via an attack on the 6-7 double bond of quinoline. Then, low-molecular-weight carboxylic acids were produced with the cleavage of aromatic ring and CO2 and H2O were the final oxidation products [53]. In the previous study, P5 was also observed in the process of ozonation of quinoline [54]. Their research focused more attention on the benzene ring opening of quinoline during the ozonation process, while a new insight into nitrogen ring opening of
quinoline during catalytic ozonation process was found in this study. 3.4. Real application to biologically pretreated coal gasification wastewater 3.4.1. Quinoline degradation and mineralization
As were shown in Fig.8, when the removal efficiency of quinoline was 100%,
TOC decreased from 67.9 mg/L to 46 mg/L with a mineralization rate of 31.5%, suggesting the production of more resistant substances. In addition, the concentration of NH3-N increased by 4.1 mg/L during the process, indicating the possible broken of C-N bonds and the generation of other N-containing oxidation products during quinoline catalytic ozonation process. 3.4.2. Biodegradability index, toxicity assessment and resazurin dehydrogenase activity
Considering the possible formation of highly toxic compounds at the early
periods of the process, B/C, toxicity assessment and resazurin dehydrogenase activity (DHA) were applied for the study of assessment of the biocompatibility of the catalytic oxidation wastewater.
As Fig.9 revealed, the B/C increased from 0.071 to 0.374 during 60 min of
catalytic ozonation process, suggesting the production of more biocompatible effluents. In addition, Fig.9 showed that the inhibition percentage of the treated solutions decreased from 53% to 28%, which was comparable with the increase of the biodegradability index. It was worth noting that there was a slight increase of toxicity at first ten minutes, which may be due to the generation of more bio-inhibitory compounds. In order to assess the biodegradability of the wastewater better after
catalytic ozonation, the test of DHA was also carried out. As shown in Fig.9, DHA increased from 177.4 to 432.9 nano-mole/h, implying the improvement of biodegradability. Similarly for the treatment of biologically pretreated coal gasification wastewater, Zhuang et al. [55] observed that the addition of sewage sludge based activated carbon supported manganese and ferric oxides catalysts can accelerate the oxidation efficiency, enhance the biodegradability and reduce the toxicity. Meanwhile, MgO based catalytic ozonation processes were found to be efficient for the improvement of biodegradability and elimination of toxic compounds [24,30,56]. All these results indicated that catalytic ozonation significantly improved the biodegradability, suggesting the possibility of catalytic ozonation pretreatment combined with biosystem for the treatment of biologically pretreated coal gasification wastewater. 3.4.3. The stability of the catalyst
From the standpoint of real applications, the stability of the catalyst was worthy
investigating. Therefore, five successive tests for catalytic ozonation of quinoline were carried out in real biologically pretreated coal gasification wastewater. At the end of each cycle, the catalyst was separated by centrifugation and the results were shown in Fig.10. It was observed that the catalytic activity was not significantly affected after five cycles, in which the degradation of quinoline was 100%, 98.32%, 97.45%, 95.34% and 93.45%, indicating the stability of the prepared catalyst. In addition, as revealed in Fig.S5, the particle size distribution before and after use of five tests was investigated. It was found that the average size of fresh MgO catalyst
changed from 17.1nm to 36.9nm after five successive tests, indicating the aggregation of used catalyst, which may be the reason for the reduction of quinoline degradation of used MgO.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
Nano-MgO was successfully prepared using homogeneous precipitation method
and it showed high efficient activity for the degradation and mineralization of quinoline in catalytic ozonation. Adsorption of quinoline on MgO was proved unimportant in O3/MgO process. Some intermediates were identified and the degradation pathway was proposed in catalytic ozonation. Nano-MgO significantly enhanced ozone decomposition into hydroxyl radicals and the catalytic mechanism mainly followed hydroxyl radicals in the bulk solution. It was found that the biodegradability of biologically pretreated coal gasification wastewater improved significantly in terms of B/C, toxicity and resazurin dehydrogenase activity after catalytic ozonation pretreatment, suggesting the possibility of catalytic ozonation combined with biosystem for this type of wastewater in the future. The catalyst remained stable catalytic activity and it was a promising catalyst for wastewater containing quinoline. In conclusion, this study provides a new insight of the application of catalytic ozonation pre-treatment in biologically pretreated coal gasification wastewater.
